This allowes for more control over for the CA scale-up simulation.

#### What type of PR is this?

#### What this PR does / why we need it:
Allows users to control the size of the pods per group in the simulation. 
This will help in cases where multiple similar pods are being scheduled.
The original hard-coded value of 10 was limiting in cases where there are 1000 of similar pods being created at once.

pull_request.title: Add support for passing custom headers to VPA requests
pull_request.body:
#### What type of PR is this?
/kind Feature

#### What this PR does / why we need it:
Add functionality for injecting custom auth headers to prometheus client requests.

#### Which issue(s) this PR fixes:
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/121507
Fixes #

#### Special notes for your reviewer:
This is just a minimal suggestion, generally it seems like the change should come from prometheus client itself, this is a minimal suggestion that might be applied in the meantime.
#### Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?
```release-note
Adding request headers injection as part of VPA round tripper.

Adding 2 CLI flags:
1. authHeaderName - supply the auth header name e.g Token
2. authHeaderValueName - supply env variable name containing the header value
```

issue.title: VPA release using Helm Chart 9.29.4

labels.name: kind/support
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as a support question.

issue.body:
Please provide any information that is related to the release:

- When we plan to do the release?

When trying to install VPA using Helm Chart

```shell
vinicius@TR-H8F87Y3:~/repos/hub/kubernetes/autoscaler/charts/cluster-autoscaler$ helm template k8s . --set vpa.enabled=true
Error: YAML parse error on cluster-autoscaler/templates/vpa.yaml: error converting YAML to JSON: yaml: line 20: did not find expected key

Use --debug flag to render out invalid YAML
```
- Are there any issues / PRs blocking the release?
Yes

comment.body:
I found the issue. Even when the VPA is installed in the cluster, you still have to specify the `containerName` in the helm chart.

I could not get the chart to install using terraform without this setup:

```yaml
vpa:
  enabled: true
  updateMode: "Auto"
  containerPolicy:
    containerName: aws-cluster-autoscaler
    minAllowed:
      cpu: 20m
      memory: 50Mi
```

Which is funny, because the final helm chart has this output. The helm chart needs updated. I don't know how you guys tested this and didn't catch this. It makes me think this wasn't tested at all.

```
    containerPolicies:
    - containerName: aws-cluster-autoscaler
      containerName: aws-cluster-autoscaler
      minAllowed:
        cpu: 20m
        memory: 50Mi
```

issue.title: Cluster autoscaler should remove unused "node-autoprovisioning-enabled" flag and the related metrics

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Denotes an issue that needs help from a contributor. Must meet "help wanted" guidelines.

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Denotes an issue ready for a new contributor, according to the "help wanted" guidelines.

issue.body:
**Which component are you using?**:

cluster-autoscaler

**What version of the component are you using?**:

Component version: 1.28.0

**What k8s version are you using (`kubectl version`)?**:

1.28.2

**What environment is this in?**:

this affects all environments

**What did you expect to happen?**:

I expect the `node-autoprovisioning-enabled` flag to change the behavior of the cluster-autoscaler when it is set or unset.

**What happened instead?**:

Changing this flag has no effect as it is essentially a left over from an earlier version of the autoscaler.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

Run the autoscaler with `--node-autoprovisioning-enabled` and without, there is no change in the behavior of the autoscaler.

**Anything else we need to know?**:

This issue was discussed during the [SIG meeting from 2023-10-23](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1RvhQAEIrVLHbyNnuaT99-6u9ZUMp7BfkPupT2LAZK7w/edit#bookmark=id.fkuqi7cc6pdn), and agree that removal is safe and the function is no longer in use.

The node autoprovisioning metrics should also be removed as part of this effort, see https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/master/cluster-autoscaler/metrics/metrics.go#L352-L375

/good-first-issue
/help

pull_request.title: Implement priority based evictor
pull_request.body:
#### What type of PR is this?
<!--
Add one of the following kinds:
/kind bug
/kind cleanup
/kind documentation
/kind feature

Optionally add one or more of the following kinds if applicable:
/kind api-change
/kind deprecation
/kind failing-test
/kind flake
/kind regression
-->
/kind bug

#### What this PR does / why we need it:
This PR implements a priority based evictor for pod eviction in scale down. This evictor can be used to enforce non-critical pods get evicted before critical pods. When this evictor is used it groups pods by priority and evicts group by group from lowest priority to highest.

#### Which issue(s) this PR fixes:
<!--
*Automatically closes linked issue when PR is merged.
Usage: `Fixes #<issue number>`, or `Fixes (paste link of issue)`.
_If PR is about `failing-tests or flakes`, please post the related issues/tests in a comment and do not use `Fixes`_*
-->
Fixes #

#### Special notes for your reviewer:

#### Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?
This PR introduces a new evictor that can be enabled and configured by ```scale-down-drain-node-priority-and-grace-periods``` flag. Setting and empty string will disable the feature and use the default unordered evictor.
<!--
If no, just write "NONE" in the release-note block below.
If yes, a release note is required:

For more information on release notes see: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/guide/release-notes.md
-->

@@ -0,0 +1,238 @@
+/*

+you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
+You may obtain a copy of the License at

+distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+limitations under the License.
+*/
+
+package actuation
+
+import (
+	"sort"
+	"strconv"
+	"strings"
+	"time"
+
+	apiv1 "k8s.io/api/core/v1"
+	v1 "k8s.io/api/core/v1"
+
+	context "k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/context"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/core/scaledown/status"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/metrics"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/simulator"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/utils/daemonset"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/utils/errors"
+	pod_util "k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/utils/pod"
+	"k8s.io/klog/v2"
+	"k8s.io/kubernetes/pkg/scheduler/framework"
+
+	kubelet_config "k8s.io/kubernetes/pkg/kubelet/apis/config"
+)
+
+// PriorityEvictor can be used to evict pods from nodes.
+type PriorityEvictor struct {
+	EvictionRetryTime                time.Duration
+	DsEvictionRetryTime              time.Duration
+	DsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout       time.Duration
+	PodEvictionHeadroom              time.Duration
+	evictionRegister                 evictionRegister
+	deleteOptions                    simulator.NodeDeleteOptions
+	shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority []kubelet_config.ShutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority
+}
+
+// NewPriorityEvictor returns an instance of PriorityEvictor using the default parameters.
+func NewPriorityEvictor(deleteOptions simulator.NodeDeleteOptions, evictionRegister evictionRegister, shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority []kubelet_config.ShutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority) PriorityEvictor {
+	sort.Slice(shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority, func(i, j int) bool {
+		return shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority[i].Priority < shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority[j].Priority
+	})
+
+	return PriorityEvictor{
+		EvictionRetryTime:                DefaultEvictionRetryTime,
+		DsEvictionRetryTime:              DefaultDsEvictionRetryTime,
+		DsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout:       DefaultDsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout,
+		PodEvictionHeadroom:              DefaultPodEvictionHeadroom,
+		evictionRegister:                 evictionRegister,
+		deleteOptions:                    deleteOptions,
+		shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority: shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority,
+	}
+}
+
+// DrainNode groups pods in the node in to priority groups and, evicts pods in the asending order of priorities.
+// All non-mirror, non-DS pods on the node are evicted. Mirror pods are not evicted.
+// DaemonSet pods are evicted if DaemonSetEvictionForOccupiedNodes is enabled, or if they have the EnableDsEvictionKey annotation.
+func (e PriorityEvictor) DrainNode(ctx *context.AutoscalingContext, nodeInfo *framework.NodeInfo) (map[string]status.PodEvictionResult, error) {
+	pods := podsToEvictCombined(ctx, nodeInfo)
+	return e.DrainNodeWithPodsBasedOnPodPriority(ctx, nodeInfo.Node(), pods)
+}
+
+// EvictDaemonSetPods creates eviction objects for all DaemonSet pods on the node.
+func (e PriorityEvictor) EvictDaemonSetPods(ctx *context.AutoscalingContext, nodeInfo *framework.NodeInfo, timeNow time.Time) error {
+	return evictDaemonSetPods(ctx, nodeInfo, timeNow, e.deleteOptions, e.DsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout, e.DsEvictionRetryTime, e.evictionRegister)
comment.body:
Yes, definitely. During scale-down, this function is called for nodes with only DS pods, while `DrainNode` is called for nodes with non-DS pods. In the current evictor, the behavior for DS pods in both these functions is more or less the same - initiate the evictions, and don't wait for the pods to disappear. We should keep the behavior the same for the new evictor as well - if `DrainNode` looks at priorities, so should the other one. From a use-case perspective, some DS pods depending on other DS pods during termination is not that much more surprising than regular pods depending on DS pods.

I actually don't think we need `EvictDaemonSetPods` at all, since the only thing that makes sense is for it to work the same as `DrainNode` anyway (for DS pods). We could just call `DrainNode` for both empty and non-empty nodes in scale-down. WDYT?

comment.body:
The extracted logic is very hard to read, I think it might be too attached to the previous flow/terminology that doesn't make sense in isolation from the rest of the eviction logic. Plus it was convoluted from the start, and adding the `ignoreDaemonSetPodEvictionResult` ifs everywhere just adds even more complexity.

WDYT about taking two separate lists of pods instead - e.g. `fullEvictionPods` and `bestEffortEvictionPods`, and treating the two separately instead of the current flow?

+
+package actuation
+
+import (
+	"sort"
+	"strconv"
+	"strings"
+	"time"
+
+	apiv1 "k8s.io/api/core/v1"
+	context "k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/context"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/core/scaledown/status"
+	"k8s.io/autoscaler/cluster-autoscaler/simulator"
+	"k8s.io/klog/v2"
+	"k8s.io/kubernetes/pkg/scheduler/framework"
+
+	kubelet_config "k8s.io/kubernetes/pkg/kubelet/apis/config"
+)
+
+// PriorityEvictor can be used to evict pods from nodes.
+type PriorityEvictor struct {
+	EvictionRetryTime                time.Duration
+	DsEvictionRetryTime              time.Duration
+	DsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout       time.Duration
+	PodEvictionHeadroom              time.Duration
+	evictionRegister                 evictionRegister
+	deleteOptions                    simulator.NodeDeleteOptions
+	shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority []kubelet_config.ShutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority
+}
+
+// NewPriorityEvictor returns an instance of PriorityEvictor using the default parameters.
+func NewPriorityEvictor(deleteOptions simulator.NodeDeleteOptions, evictionRegister evictionRegister, shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority []kubelet_config.ShutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority) PriorityEvictor {
+	sort.Slice(shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority, func(i, j int) bool {
+		return shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority[i].Priority < shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority[j].Priority
+	})
+
+	return PriorityEvictor{
+		EvictionRetryTime:                DefaultEvictionRetryTime,
+		DsEvictionRetryTime:              DefaultDsEvictionRetryTime,
+		DsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout:       DefaultDsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout,
+		PodEvictionHeadroom:              DefaultPodEvictionHeadroom,
+		evictionRegister:                 evictionRegister,
+		deleteOptions:                    deleteOptions,
+		shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority: shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority,
+	}
+}
+
+// DrainNode groups pods in the node in to priority groups and, evicts pods in the ascending order of priorities.
+// All non-mirror, non-DS pods on the node are evicted. Mirror pods are not evicted.
+// DaemonSet pods are evicted if DaemonSetEvictionForOccupiedNodes is enabled, or if they have the EnableDsEvictionKey annotation.
+func (e PriorityEvictor) DrainNode(ctx *context.AutoscalingContext, nodeInfo *framework.NodeInfo) (map[string]status.PodEvictionResult, error) {
+	pods, dsPods := podsToEvict(ctx, nodeInfo)
+	return e.DrainNodeWithPodsBasedOnPodPriority(ctx, nodeInfo.Node(), append(pods, dsPods...))
+}
+
+// EvictDaemonSetPods creates eviction objects for all DaemonSet pods on the node.
+func (e PriorityEvictor) EvictDaemonSetPods(ctx *context.AutoscalingContext, nodeInfo *framework.NodeInfo) error {
+	return evictDaemonSetPods(ctx, nodeInfo, e.deleteOptions, e.DsEvictionEmptyNodeTimeout, e.DsEvictionRetryTime, e.evictionRegister)
+}
+
+// DrainNodeWithPodsBasedOnPodPriority performs drain logic on the node based on pod priorities. Marks the node as unschedulable and
+// later removes all pods, giving them up to MaxGracefulTerminationTime to finish. The list of pods to evict has to be provided.
+func (e PriorityEvictor) DrainNodeWithPodsBasedOnPodPriority(ctx *context.AutoscalingContext, node *apiv1.Node, pods []*apiv1.Pod) (map[string]status.PodEvictionResult, error) {
+	return drainNodeWithPodsBasedOnPodPriority(ctx, node, pods, e.shutdownGracePeriodByPodPriority, false, e.EvictionRetryTime, e.evictionRegister, e.PodEvictionHeadroom)
comment.body:
Am I getting it right that the only difference between the two Evictors is the `ignoreDaemonSetPodEvictionResult` parameter to `drainNodeWithPodsBasedOnPodPriority`? If that's true, maybe we should merge the two implementations after all, and just parameterize it with whether it should evict DS pods fully, or best-effort? If a user configures the old flag, in initialization we'd turn it into the single priority group + pass "best-effort DS eviction" to the evictor. If a user configures the new flag, we'd just parse the groups + pass "full DS eviction". 

That would remove a lot of redundancy (the struct params, constructor etc), and we could keep the logic from drain.go as methods, so we'd pass fewer things by arguments. WDYT?

 	maxAllocatableDifferenceRatio           = flag.Float64("max-allocatable-difference-ratio", config.DefaultMaxAllocatableDifferenceRatio, "Maximum difference in allocatable resources between two similar node groups to be considered for balancing. comment.body:
Sorry, I meant the `max-graceful-termination-sec` flag in my previous comment, not `max-pod-eviction-time`. `max-pod-eviction-time` works the same for both Evictors, but `max-graceful-termination-sec` and `scale-down-drain-node-priority-and-grace-periods` configure mutually exclusive components, so their interaction should be well-defined. For example, we could disallow using them together, or always prefer one of them if both are set. Disallowing seems the clearest though, since if one of the flags is set the other just doesn't make sense.

Also, I'd change the outer separator to just a comma, including a single space is a bit weird for configs.

pull_request.body:
#### What type of PR is this?
<!--
Add one of the following kinds:

/kind flake
/kind regression

#### What this PR does / why we need it:
This PR implements a priority based evictor for pod eviction in scale down. This evictor can be used to enforce non-critical pods get evicted before critical pods. When this evictor is used it groups pods by priority and evicts group by group from lowest priority to highest.

issue.title: Cluster autoscaler should remove unused "node-autoprovisioning-enabled" flag and the related metrics

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.

issue.body:
**Which component are you using?**:

cluster-autoscaler

**What version of the component are you using?**:

Component version: 1.28.0

**What k8s version are you using (`kubectl version`)?**:

1.28.2

**What environment is this in?**:

this affects all environments

**What did you expect to happen?**:

I expect the `node-autoprovisioning-enabled` flag to change the behavior of the cluster-autoscaler when it is set or unset.

**What happened instead?**:

Changing this flag has no effect as it is essentially a left over from an earlier version of the autoscaler.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

Run the autoscaler with `--node-autoprovisioning-enabled` and without, there is no change in the behavior of the autoscaler.

**Anything else we need to know?**:

This issue was discussed during the [SIG meeting from 2023-10-23](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1RvhQAEIrVLHbyNnuaT99-6u9ZUMp7BfkPupT2LAZK7w/edit#bookmark=id.fkuqi7cc6pdn), and agree that removal is safe and the function is no longer in use.

The node autoprovisioning metrics should also be removed as part of this effort, see https://github.com/kubernetes/autoscaler/blob/master/cluster-autoscaler/metrics/metrics.go#L352-L375

/good-first-issue
/help

pull_request.title: Bump CA golang to 1.21
pull_request.body:
#### What type of PR is this?

/kind cleanup

#### What this PR does / why we need it:

Bump cluster-autoscaler golang version to 1.21.
The Docker build was already using `golang:1.21.3` - it's only the CI and go.mod that was lacking behind.
K/K is already on 1.21.3 as well: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/.go-version

With upgrade, I've removed min/max functions, which are now build-in: https://tip.golang.org/ref/spec#Min_and_max

#### Does this PR introduce a user-facing change?
```release-note
NONE
```
